problems.title: Suspension
problems.statementHtml:
A game is being played which initially consists of nn players. On fouls, the referee is allowed to award yellow and red cards. The total number of yellow cards yy and red cards rr awarded to players is known for the game.

There are 22 ways a player can be suspended:

Once a player is suspended, they are removed from the game and can't receive any more cards. Determine the maximum number of players suspended from the game possible.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤5001≤t≤500). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (1≤n≤1001≤n≤100).

The second line of each test case contains two integers yy and rr (0≤r≤n0≤r≤n, 0≤y+r≤2n0≤y+r≤2n).
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print one line containing a single integer — denoting the maximum number of players suspended from the game possible.
problems.noteHtml:
For the first test case:

  • One of the possible ways to achieve maximum: Player 22 receives a red card, Player 33 receives a yellow card followed by a red card.
  • This way Player 22 and 33 are suspended.

For the second test case:

  • No cards are awarded at all, so no one is suspended.

For the third test case:

  • One of the possible ways to achieve maximum: Player 11 receives 22 yellow cards, Player 22 receives 22 yellow cards, and Player 44 receives 22 yellow cards.
  • This way Player 11, 22, and 44 are suspended.

problems.title: Split
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a sequence aa containing 2n2n integers. Let f(b)f(b) denote the number of distinct elements with an odd number of occurrences in sequence bb. You need to split the given array into two disjoint subsequences pp and qq, each of size nn, such that f(p)+f(q)f(p)+f(q) is maximized. Output the maximum value.

A sequence aa is a subsequence of a sequence bb if aa can be obtained from bb by the deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) element from arbitrary positions.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line contains 2n2n integers a1,a2,…,a2na1,a2,…,a2n (1≤ai≤2n1≤ai≤2n) — the elements of sequence aa.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, print one line.

You have to print the maximum value of f(p)+f(q)f(p)+f(q) that can be achieved.
problems.noteHtml:
For the first test case:

  • We can divide the array such that p=[1,3]p=[1,3] and q=[2,4]q=[2,4].
  • This way, f(p)=2f(p)=2 and f(q)=2f(q)=2 since both have two distinct elements with odd frequency.

For the second test case:

  • We can divide the array such that p=[5,5,5]p=[5,5,5] and q=[5,5,5]q=[5,5,5].
  • This way, f(p)=1f(p)=1 and f(q)=1f(q)=1.

For the fifth test case:

  • We can divide the array such that p=[1,2,3,4,5,6]p=[1,2,3,4,5,6] and q=[4,1,4,1,5,4]q=[4,1,4,1,5,4].
  • This way, f(p)=6f(p)=6 and f(q)=2f(q)=2.

problems.title: Annoying Game
problems.statementHtml:
You are given two integer arrays aa and bb, both of length nn, and a total number of turns kk.

Alice and Bob play a game by taking turns modifying array aa. Alice goes first. The game lasts for exactly kk turns.

On their turn, a player must choose an index ii (1≤i≤n1≤i≤n) and perform one of the following operations:

After the kk-th turn is complete, the final score is calculated as the maximum non-empty subarray sum of the modified array aa. Alice's goal is to maximize the final score, while Bob's goal is to minimize the final score.

Assuming both players play optimally to achieve their respective goals, determine the final score.

The maximum non-empty subarray sum of aa is defined as max1≤i≤j≤nS(i,j)max1≤i≤j≤nS(i,j), where S(i,j)=ai+ai+1+⋯+ajS(i,j)=ai+ai+1+⋯+aj. Note that empty subarrays are not considered.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (1≤n≤2⋅1051≤n≤2⋅105, 1≤k≤2⋅1051≤k≤2⋅105) — the length of the arrays and the total number of turns.

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (−109≤ai≤109−109≤ai≤109) — the elements of array aa.

The third line contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (0≤bi≤1090≤bi≤109) — the elements of array bb.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, print a single integer — the final score after kk turns, assuming both players play optimally.
problems.noteHtml:
For the first test case:

  • Any move can't change the array aa because all elements in bb are zero.
  • The maximum non-empty subarray sum of this final array is 3+(−1)+9=113+(−1)+9=11.

For the second test case, one of the possible optimal sequences of moves is:

  • Alice adds b3=1b3=1 to a3a3. Array aa becomes [10,10,11,10][10,10,11,10].
  • Bob subtracts b1=1b1=1 from a1a1. Array aa becomes [9,10,11,10][9,10,11,10].
  • Alice adds b3=1b3=1 to a3a3. Array aa becomes [9,10,12,10][9,10,12,10].
  • Bob subtracts b1=1b1=1 from a1a1. Array aa becomes [8,10,12,10][8,10,12,10].
  • Alice adds b4=1b4=1 to a4a4. Array aa becomes [8,10,12,11][8,10,12,11].
  • The maximum non-empty subarray sum of this final array is 8+10+12+11=418+10+12+11=41.

For the third test case, one of the possible optimal sequences of moves is:

  • Alice adds b2=11b2=11 to a2a2. Array aa becomes [2,4,3][2,4,3].
  • The maximum non-empty subarray sum of this final array is 2+4+3=92+4+3=9.

For the fourth test case, one of the possible optimal sequences of moves is:

  • Alice adds b2=11b2=11 to a2a2. Array aa becomes [2,4,3][2,4,3].
  • Bob subtracts b2=11b2=11 from a2a2. Array aa becomes [2,−7,3][2,−7,3].
  • The maximum non-empty subarray sum of this final array is 33.

problems.title: Palindrome Flipping
problems.statementHtml:
You are given two binary strings ss and tt, each of the same length nn. You are allowed to perform the following operation:

The goal is to finally make ss equal to tt, performing any of the above operations at most 2n2n times (possibly none).

A substring sl,rsl,r of a string ss is the contiguous sequence of characters starting from index ll and ending at index rr (both inclusive), where 1≤l<r≤|s|1≤l<r≤|s|. Here |s||s| denotes the length of the string ss.

A string is a palindrome if it reads the same forwards and backwards. For example, the strings 101 and 00 are palindromes, while 10 is not.

Flipping all bits in a substring means changing each 0 to 1 and each 1 to 0 in that substring. For example, flipping the substring 101 results in 010.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases TT (1≤T≤5⋅1031≤T≤5⋅103). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (4≤n≤1004≤n≤100) — the length of the strings ss and tt.

The next two lines of each test case contain the binary strings ss and tt, respectively.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n2n2 over all test cases does not exceed 5⋅1055⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, if it is impossible to achieve the goal, print −1−1.

Otherwise, the first line should contain an integer kk (0≤k≤2n0≤k≤2n) — the number of operations.

For each of the next kk lines, print two integers l,rl,r (1≤l<r≤n1≤l<r≤n) — the indices you choose in each operation. Note that sl,rsl,r must be a palindrome at this stage.
problems.noteHtml:
For the first test case:

  • Initially, s=01011s=01011 and t=10000t=10000.
  • First, we choose l=1l=1 and r=3r=3. This is a valid operation since s1,3=010s1,3=010 is a palindrome. After flipping s1,3s1,3, s=10111s=10111.
  • Then, we choose l=3l=3 and r=5r=5. This is a valid operation since s3,5=111s3,5=111 is a palindrome. After flipping s3,5s3,5, s=10000s=10000.
  • Now, ss is equal to tt.

For the second test case:

  • Initially, s=1010101s=1010101 and t=0101010t=0101010.
  • First, we choose l=1l=1 and r=7r=7. This is a valid operation since s1,7=1010101s1,7=1010101 is a palindrome. After flipping s1,7s1,7, s=0101010s=0101010.
  • Now, ss is equal to tt.

For the third test case:

  • Initially, ss is equal to tt. No operations are needed.

problems.title: Sink
problems.statementHtml:
You are given a grid containing nn rows and mm columns. Every cell (i,j)(i,j), located in the ii-th row and jj-th column, has a positive integer value associated with it ai,jai,j. Two cells are adjacent if and only if they share a common side in the grid.

You are allowed to construct holes at cells of your choice. A cell (x,y)(x,y) is a sink if and only if it has a hole, or is adjacent to a sink (i,j)(i,j) with ax,y≥ai,jax,y≥ai,j.

The beauty of a grid is defined as the minimum number of holes you need to construct so that every cell becomes a sink.

You have to determine the beauty of this grid.

You are also given qq queries.

In a query, you are given three positive integers rr, cc, and xx. The current value of cell (r,c)(r,c) is decreased by xx. After each query, determine the beauty of the grid considering no holes have been constructed yet.

Note that queries are cumulative, so the effects of each query carry on to future queries.

It is guaranteed that after every query the value of each cell will remain positive.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (1≤n,m≤2⋅1051≤n,m≤2⋅105, 1≤n⋅m≤2⋅1051≤n⋅m≤2⋅105) — the number of rows and columns, respectively.

The following nn lines contain mm integers each; the jj-th element in the ii-th line ai,jai,j is the number written in the jj-th cell of the ii-th row (1≤ai,j≤1091≤ai,j≤109).

The next line contains a single integer qq (0≤q≤2⋅1050≤q≤2⋅105) — the number of queries.

The following qq lines contain 33 integers each — r,c,r,c, and xx (1≤r≤n,1≤c≤m,1≤x<1091≤r≤n,1≤c≤m,1≤x<109).

It is guaranteed that the sum of n⋅mn⋅m and the sum of qq over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.

It is guaranteed that after every query the value of each cell will remain positive.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, print q+1q+1 lines.

On the first line print the beauty of the initial grid.

Also, after each query, print the beauty of the current grid.
problems.noteHtml:
For the first test case:

  • Initially, we can create a hole at cell (1,11,1).
  • After the first query, we can create a hole at cell (1,11,1).
  • After the second query, we can create holes at cells (1,11,1) and (1,31,3).

For the second test case:

  • Initially, we can create holes at cells (1,21,2), (2,12,1), (2,32,3), and (3,23,2).
  • After the first query, we can create holes at cells (1,21,2), (2,12,1), (2,32,3), and (3,23,2).
  • After the second query, we can create a hole at cell (2,22,2).
  • After the third query, we can create holes at cells (2,22,2) and (3,33,3).

problems.title: Distinct GCDs (Easy Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, n≤700n≤700. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

Legend has it that when Gauss was a young schoolboy, his teacher tasked the class with summing the integers from 11 to 100100, likely as a way to keep them occupied for a while. However, young Gauss quickly came up with the formula sum=n(n+1)2sum=n(n+1)2 and found the answer in mere moments. Centuries later, Gauss appears before you in a nightmare with a daunting task...

You are given a positive integer nn, find a sequence of integers [a1,a2,…,an][a1,a2,…,an] such that 1≤ai≤10181≤ai≤1018 for all 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, and the GCDs of pairwise adjacent elements of aa are all distinct. Formally,

Additionally, aa should have the minimum possible number of distinct elements.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤2001≤t≤200). The description of the test cases follows.

The first and only line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤7002≤n≤700) — the size of the sequence to be found.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output nn space-separated positive integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤10181≤ai≤1018) on a new line that satisfy the condition in the statement. If there are multiple solutions, print any of them.

It can be proven that under the problem constraints, a solution always exists.
problems.noteHtml:
For the second test case, the GCDs of adjacent elements are [gcd(1,4),gcd(4,4),gcd(4,6),gcd(6,6)]=[1,4,2,6][gcd(1,4),gcd(4,4),gcd(4,6),gcd(6,6)]=[1,4,2,6], all of which are distinct.

For the third test case, the GCDs of adjacent elements are [gcd(4,4),gcd(4,6),gcd(6,6),gcd(6,9),gcd(9,9),gcd(9,4)]=[4,2,6,3,9,1][gcd(4,4),gcd(4,6),gcd(6,6),gcd(6,9),gcd(9,9),gcd(9,4)]=[4,2,6,3,9,1], all of which are distinct.

For each test case, it can be proven that no sequence with fewer distinct elements exists such that all adjacent GCDs are distinct.

problems.title: Distinct GCDs (Hard Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the hard version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, n≤5000n≤5000. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

Legend has it that when Gauss was a young schoolboy, his teacher tasked the class with summing the integers from 11 to 100100, likely as a way to keep them occupied for a while. However, young Gauss quickly came up with the formula sum=n(n+1)2sum=n(n+1)2 and found the answer in mere moments. Centuries later, Gauss appears before you in a nightmare with a daunting task...

You are given a positive integer nn, find a sequence of integers [a1,a2,…,an][a1,a2,…,an] such that 1≤ai≤10181≤ai≤1018 for all 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, and the GCDs of pairwise adjacent elements of aa are all distinct. Formally,

Additionally, aa should have the minimum possible number of distinct elements.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤2001≤t≤200). The description of the test cases follows.

The first and only line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤50002≤n≤5000) — the size of the sequence to be found.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output nn space-separated positive integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤10181≤ai≤1018) on a new line that satisfy the condition in the statement. If there are multiple solutions, print any of them.

It can be proven that under the problem constraints, a solution always exists.
problems.noteHtml:
For the second test case, the GCDs of adjacent elements are [gcd(1,4),gcd(4,4),gcd(4,6),gcd(6,6)]=[1,4,2,6][gcd(1,4),gcd(4,4),gcd(4,6),gcd(6,6)]=[1,4,2,6], all of which are distinct.

For the third test case, the GCDs of adjacent elements are [gcd(4,4),gcd(4,6),gcd(6,6),gcd(6,9),gcd(9,9),gcd(9,4)]=[4,2,6,3,9,1][gcd(4,4),gcd(4,6),gcd(6,6),gcd(6,9),gcd(9,9),gcd(9,4)]=[4,2,6,3,9,1], all of which are distinct.

For each test case, it can be proven that no sequence with fewer distinct elements exists such that all adjacent GCDs are distinct.

tutorial.contentHtml:
2158A - Suspension Idea & Solution: kingmessi

Hint 1

Each red card immediately suspends a player. What is the best way to use rr red cards to maximize the number of distinct suspended players?
